div.head: SCENE I.—Hall of Audience in King Ferdinand’s Palace. KING, QUEEN, and an entire pack of court cards, discovered.
COMPLIMENTARY CHORUS,["Gustavus,”]by the courtiers, enthusiastic and ecomiastic, as in duty bound.

lg.l: Hail! oh, king of Arragon!
Reign! oh, princely paragon!
Down upon your marrowbone, all the Lords kneel R.L.S.
Long live the king!
Monarch mightier is he, sir,
Than Joe Smith or Julius Cæsar,
Brigham Young or Nebuchudnezzar,
Long live the king!
And hail to Isabella, too,
For she’s a right good fellow, too,
And a right good tune to bellow to,
Is long live the queen!
She’s fairer than the fairest fairy,
Sweeter than the Scottish Mary,
Nymph or Nereiad there’s n’ary
One like our queen.

div.stage: end of music Shouts. [Cheers from the administration.

lg.l: This cheering fire, defenders of the great,
Is grateful to our royal tympanum, of late
Elated by our victories among
Those mongrel Moors, to hear our praises sung
We’ve had no time; but now the wars are ended,
And in the usual way, our faith defended,
That is by slaying every slavish minion
Who dares to differ with us in opinion.
Although by proxy those great deeds were done,
We think we’ve earned the right to have some fun;
So loud let every office-holder shout,
Or else we’ll send them to the right about.
Louder, you puddin’ heads, aldermen and all, Shout.
Or else our city hall we’ll overhaul,
And cut your heavy jobs and contracts down,
And then we’ll see who’ll represent the town.
Tell us what news is stirring in the city? Shout. Rises and comes down with Queen (arrives with Queen)
So please you, sire, the Vigilance Committee
A foolish foreigner this day has found,
Who swears, confound him, that the world is round, Shout. Astonished
And swings, on what the fellow calls its axis,
Just once a year.
It taxes both credulity and patience
To listen to the mountebank’s relations.
Perhaps he’s right—let’s ask him here to sup,
There may be something in—

sp.speaker: Fonseca.
sp.l: But that’s not all he says.

lg.l: I want to know.
What does he say?
He says, my liege, below
There is a corresponding half-world—
We know better
For did it correspond we’d have a letter. Laughs
We’ve nothing from that latitude, in fine
We hav’n’t had an equinoctial line— Laughs
So it’s all bosh.
‘Twould be as well to hear
The man himself.
And more than this—your majesty will laugh,
Of course—the fool asserts, the other half
Has mountains, vallies, seas, just like our own;
With men and women—
What, turned upside down! Laughs
Strange kind of man, to think mankind, like flies,
Could in such strange position stand—he lies.
But, above all, the chap maintains that gold
And precious gems lie there in heaps untold.
And pearls of countless price,
Rubies and amethysts.
Take my advice
And look into this matter.
You look out;
Bell, hold your tongue—we know what we’re about.
Let some one summon here this foreign catiff
Who thus presumes to know more than a native.
Hast heard his name?
I like it—’tis the type of peace and love—.
You called me so at first.
Be quiet, do;
Don’t talk, my dove, until you headr your coo.
Who is this pigeon?

div.stage:
Columbus. Pedlers tray with trinkets &c.
Diego. Box with Pop-corn
Twelve candelsticks ready R.3.E.

lg.l: I saw him hawking
Some maps and charts; sad and fatigued with walking,
He rested on a convent step—his son
Lay near him, hunger-pinched and wan
With weakness—yet the heartless crowd passed on,
Even without the tribute of a sigh.
At length, a poor friar, himself not overfed,
Gave to the wanderers a loaf of bread.
The gift was timely, yet the proud man’s soul,
I plainly saw, revolted at the dole,
Although ‘twas thankfully received. He woke
The famine-stricken boy, and quickly broke
The loaf in two—one half the lad received,
And with such ravenous haste—it deeper grieved
The sorrowing man. I read his anxious fears;
I saw the dry crust moistened with his tears,
And turned away dimsighted and heart-sick.
I’ll take my oath that friar was a brick.
He’s poor, it seems, despite of all his pains—
Then, ten to one, the fellow’s cursed with brains.
If so, I’ll steal ‘em, for mere brains alone are
Seldom any use to the first owner.
Such madman’s words, how shall we style ‘em?
The ass has broke from some asylum;
A world across the western sea!
‘Twon’t do, Columbus—no, siree.
Scizzerrere!
Oh fel magia mosbio
As a marchera, che si won’t returno,
Scizzerere!
Ti himup to some trio,
Predo, for here he cant Soggiurno!
Bi guingo, lam orti the crowdo,
Astar, nota onei se nir.
Ah mi tiseri—
Ah mi tiseri Mustay.
Hadio hadio buta dimo
To geta Sangarie.
Du tell, du tel guist erim
The luni supposes notin.
Scizzerere!
De te nim ti Sonli ad ute uno.

div.l: De te nim O damit, de te nim O no.

lg.l: Go, bring him in— and now we’ll pump him dryer Exeunt 4 pages L.2.E.
Than the dry crust he got from that same friar.
Bell, if there’s any tin,
You’ll tintinnabulate—I mean ring in.
If there’s a chance, the main one you won’t lose,
But caution and precaution both we’ll use.
We’ll see this mariner—if aught accrues
From his projected cruise, we won’t reject it,
But with the glory of our reign connect it.
By our own royal judgment we’ll abide,
And if we find him slippery, let him slide.
I hope your majesty will deign to pause.
Before this man, who scouts our mundane laws,
You thus encourage—our estate it shocks
That he should trifle with the orthodox.
The church has settled that the world is flat.
There cannot be the slightest doubt of that.
He comes—don’t fear, we’ll find out his intents. Music

div.stage:
Enter COLUMBUS, peddling stationery & Diego 2.E.L., with cigar box.
Re-Enter 2.E.L.H. 4 pages go to former places

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Twenty-five maps of the world for four cents.

sp.speaker: Diego
sp.l: Pop corn ginger nuts and apples. goes around the crowd

lg.l: Who are you, stranger, that with daring speech
A new cosmogany presume to teach?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: A ci-devant poor flat-boat captain, sire.

lg.l: Flat broke ‘twould seem to judge from your attire.
Go on, unfold yourself, pay out.
My lord, I will.
Will you oblige me with the chord? [To leader
Mio simplissima storio dost thou requesto,
Oh give earo unto mi relazioni,
But if this foreign lingo, you cannot digesto
I’ll try the purissimo Anglo Saxoni.
My name it is Columbus, I was born in Genoa
Of poor but honest parents, so the story always goes.
My father was a mariner, and he mar-ri-ed my mother there,
And I was the offspring as you may readily suppose.
Sweet infancy’s days when the brain very little wit is in,
As is mostly the case passed unconciously bye,
Oh my parent’s expected I’d become a steady sober citizen,
But I was bound to be a sailor boy, by jingo, or die.
For many a long year I have plough’d the wild ocean,
And many strange notians and natives have seen,
But now in my head I have got a sort of notion
That there’s some place else somewhere that aint been seen yet.
To find this place out is the only thing I live for,
Ambition and fame in that single path lie
Just to help me along some assistance pray give, for
I’m bound to find Columbia, by jingo, or die!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What is’thave youv’e got within your silly brain?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: A Main land, sire, there is beyond the Main.

lg.l: Stop a minute—
We’ll hear him talk, there may be something in it.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Pearls and rubies grow there, we are told?—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now do be quiet;—aye, and lots of gold.

lg.l: I’m almost weary, sire, of telling o’er
To Princes all the gifts I have in store,
For him who will accept the golden key,
And will for such a chance my patron be.
To my own land I fain would give the prize,
But there was no speculation in their eyes,
And not a real but to realise
My ardent Spirit’s hope’s, would they advance,
French leave I took of them, and unto France
Laden with gall, pursued my weary way,
But the great Lewis had by reckless play
Collapsed his treasury, for like a stoker
The British King had singed him at drawpoker,
The winning King I tried, while he was flush,
But for my suit he did’nt care a rush,
Now sad and broken down, I’ve wandered here,
Without one ray my onward path to cheer—
The street my lodgingchamber, and the stones my bed,
An airy lodging for I’ve ‘nary red!
Audacious peddler! what is this we hear—
You say our World is but a hemisphere,
And there’s another somewhere under ground
That joined with it goes always’s bobbing round.
Well, that’s a round assertion—
Then tell us, if you please, just for diversion,
What does it rest on?
Circum-fiddlesticks—you are a case!
And what’s the reason that it doesn’t drop?
In endless revolution like a top
It sleeps,—thus exquisitely poised in air
By equalized attraction.
Fool—beware!
We cannot listen to such words as these,
The stake has blazed for lighter heresies!
A lunatic—there’s not a doubt of that—
But in the meal-tub there may be a cat.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Poor man! We must do something for him.

lg.l: Stay!
Wait ‘till we find out if the thing will pay,
Friend Christopher, we’re sorry for your plight,
But pledge our royal word to make it right
If to our realm you’ll add some foreign nation,
Rich and disposed to stand extreme taxation,
Prove you can do this, so that none can doubt it,
And we shall give you—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: But, sire, my scheme needs money.

lg.l: Well, then share it—
Get up a joint stock and don’t over-“bear” it.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Craft I must have to sail in.

lg.l: “Quantum suf.”
Once you’re in Wall street, you’ll find craft enough,
You dreamy fellow’s, that don’t know the ropes
Sit down and starve upon your empty hopes,
While sharper dunces thrive.
I fain would know
The way.
To raise the wind you’ll have to “blow,”
We’ll call our company—“the Anti-Panic
Perpetual Gold Producing Oceanic,”
And true de facto high old “Life and Trust—“
Bound in due time to spread itself—
Of course, but not tillWhen it is formed there we'll go in and win,
Capital we’ll call five millions to begin.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: I shall not need a third.

lg.l: Oh! have no fears,—
We must provide for fast clerks and cashiers,
Armies of “Blowers”—“Runners” and “Advisers”—
“Committees”—“Lobbyers” and “Advertisers”—
And for your president a small gratuity.
Some thirty thousand would’nt hurt us.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You would’nt go below our friends in Erie—

lg.l: My aspirations, sire, you only mock
Who would be fools enough to take such stock:
Who, Sir?—Why everybody! what stupidity,
If you but nicely tickle their cupidity!
I’ll prove it in an instant. King goes C. Sits in State chair.Ho! a Court!movement of the Lords & Ladies
My lords, we’re going to make you a report
Of the first meeting for consolidation,
Of our new filibustering association,—
I mean for the encouragement of emigration,—
Present—the president, myself—ahem!
Secretary and Treasurer pro tem—
Profits enormous, and the outlay small.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: An old man’s wearied life, perhaps, that’s all.

lg.l: Who’ll venture while the wheel of fortune whirls,
Dividend’s paid in gold or Jersey pearls:
You should’nt let a chance like this go bye.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: CardinalArchbishop, you a byer? King advances centre

sp.speaker: Fonseca.
sp.l: Prudence is a cardinal virtue, sire.

lg.l: Now we must try the street—Pope say’s you know,
Man wants but [Jacob] little here below—
And we’re all right. L.H.
Then care and sorrow’s past,
Hope dawns and life’s worth living for at last!

stage.l: Cardinal R. Queen R.C. Columbus L.C. King L.

lg.l: Just as sure as fate
He’s in a beautiful clairvoyant state!
Columbus! Why are you in such amaze?
Time onward passes, and my mental gaze
Is on the future, lo! I see a land
Where nature seems to frame with practised hand
Her last most wonderous work! before me rise
Mountains of solid rock that rift the skies,—
Imperial vallies with rich verdure crowned
For leagues illimitable smile around,
While through them subject seas for rivers run
From ice bonnd tracts to where the tropic sun
Breeds in the teeming ooze strange monstrous things—
I see upswelling from exhaustless springs,
Great lakes appear upon whose surface wide
The banded navies of the earth may ride,
I see tremendous cataract’s emerge
From cloud aspiring heights, whose slippery verge
Tremendous ocean’s momently roll o’er,
Assaulting with unmitigated roar
The stunned and shattered ear of trembling day
That wounded, weeps in glistening tears of spray!
We grieve your sensibility to shock,
See something else or down will go our stock.
I see upspringing from the fruitful breast
Of the beneficent and boundless West,
Uncounted acres of life-giving grain,
Wave o’er the gently undulating plain,
So tall each blade that you can scarcely touch
The top!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ah! now, my blade, you see too much.

lg.l: Within the limits of the southern zone
I see plantations, thickly overgrown
With a small shrub in whose white flower lies
A revenue of millions!
You surprise
Us now, we’ll cotton to that tree!
Go on, old fellow, what else do you see?
From which men can evoke
Profit as wonderful!
Ah, now you’re in the clouds again. Good gracious!
Think of the stock, and don’t be so fugacious.
I see a river, through whose limpid stream,
Pacstolus like, the yellow pebbles gleam;
Flowing through regions, where great heaps of gold,
Uncared for, lie in affluence untold,
Thick as autumnal leaves, the precious store.
My eyes! why didn’t you see that before?
We’ll go ourself, we mean we shall “go in.”
Go on.
I see small villages begin,
Like twilight stars, to peep forth timidly,
Great distances apart; and now I see
Towns, swol’n to cities, burst upon the sight,
Thick as the crowded firmament at night.
I see brave science, with inspired soul,
Subdue the elements to its control;
On iron ways, through rock and mountain riven,
Impelling mighty freights, by vapor driven;
Or with electric nerves so interlace
The varied points of universal space.
Thought answers thought, though scores of miles between—
Time is outstripped—and naught is that has been.
My friend, come, ain’t you getting rather steep?
We beg to probability you’ll keep.
What see you now?
The plethora of wealth
Corrupt and undermine the general health.
I see vile madd’ning fumes incite to strife,
Obscure the sense and whet the murderer’s knife.
I see dead rabbits—
I see above the land the war clouds lower
Pregnant with death and madness rule the hour
And now I see her unpolluted shield
More brightly shine in battle fires unneeded
And the sole taint that tarnished her fair name
We've purified in freedom’s sacred flame.
I see investigations—
That’s enough—give o’er;
It won’t be prudent to see any more.
You’ve evidently over-taxed your head—
Just take a whiskey skin and go to bed.
Meantime, we give our royal approbation
To your grand scheme of general annexation;
And that in stealing gold you may not cease,
Receive the order of the “Golden Fleece.”
I must keep dark—of course you have the “nous”
To pass judiciously the custom house.
It will be hard, I know, to put the blinders
Upon the new marshall Don Isaiah Rynders.
Our freight, mere farming implements we’ll call—
A cargo of threshing machines—that’s all.
The oyster trade just now is rather bad,
We know a couple of sloops that can be had
Dirt cheap for cash. We’ll give you the command,
And you can start at once.
I’ll be on hand
At any moment, sire, that you propose—
My trunk is packed, when I put on my clothes.
Hope and your royal favor to my heart
Ambition impulse energy impart,
Ere long, like swelling sails, to be unfurled;
Blow, friendly gales, they’ll bring you back a world.
Bring back a world! that would be, I must say,
Handsome return for such a small outlay.
W?? leave your son with us him will engage
Now would you like to be a royal page
Oh! Wouldn’t I, for such a high condition
I’d sacrifice my mercantile position.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Have then your wish, you shall attend on us

sp.speaker: Diego
sp.l: Ain’t I a jolly lucky little cuss.
Farewell my stock in trade farewell my store
I’ll give up business now and shut the door.

lg.l: Dear me! does anybody know how late
It is?
Well, don’t you worry;
We’ll go to bed, but as we’re in a hurry—
The scene must operatically end—
We’ll sing good night to our distinguished friend.

div.stage: SLEEPY CHORUS, with yawning accompaniment, in which it is hoped the spectators will not join. L1E

stage.add: Exit Diego 3.E.R. and returns with lighted candles (say 12)

lg.l: We are so nappy that to bed we must start,
The courtier doth easily lie;
To make us happy, though before we depart,
A night-cap I’ll have on the sly.
Oh deary me, how sleepy are we,
Ye—ah!—aw! [yawning,] &c.
Sonny, all right, good night,
We’ll meet at breakfast in the morning,
And take a bite when the early light
Of the morn gets up, the dawn adorning.
In all the independent journals
We’ll have a first-rate notice;
To succeed without the aid of the diurnals,
We know now-a-day no go ’tis, &c., &c.

div.stage: [All go off with bed candlesticks.

div.head: SCENE II.—A modest and retiring apartment in the palace.

stage.p: change: White night cap & white night Robe for King ready R.H.1.E. All closed in 1.G. Music continues till Columbus on, in Scene 2nd. Brings on chair & Goblet of Whiskey Punch. Spoon & lemon &c ready Change.

div.stage: COLUMBUS enters with a nightcap, which, in a moment of abstraction, he swallows. L1E

lg.l: I’ve made a precious bargain here, I swear—
This downey king expects the lion’s share
And hasn’t taken one, the common way
In which the poor world-worker gets his pay.
On one side, enterprise, toil, danger, death!
And on the other, mouthfuls of mere breath.
A vain man—worshipped, transitory name,
But ah! to sparkle in the heaven of fame
Eternal as itself, and life outlast,
Still ever-present in the living past.
To think one’s memory may fill unsought
A Sovran throne within the realm of thought,
When piled up centuries their shadow flings
Across the records of forgotten kings;
What to such destiny are earthly joys?

div.stage: FERDINAND, (the king,)—in robe de chambre, and nightcapped & lighted candle—looks from door, F. R.1.E.

lg.l: Friend Christopher, you’re making too much noise;
Please to remember this is not an inn.
I beg your pardon, sire, it was the gin;
By that, and your kind promises elated,
I own I did feel somewhat elevated.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Well, just blow off your froth and settle down. [Exit. 1.E.R.

lg.l: All right, your majesty. Oh, great renown,
What slights aspiring poverty endures
That through such patrons the great prize secures;
It riles me even now, to think this thing
In after ages to my fame will cling,
And like dead fruit upon the living tree,
Hang on to my green immortality.
Could this mean king, unless by my deserving,
Awake the genius of a Prescott or an Irving!
There’s no use moralizing now, because
What will be will be, as what has been was.
And talking of what will be—a strange thought
Just crossed my mind with difficulty fraught:
If some small scribbler, in a future day,
Should try to weave my story in a play,
I’m curious now to know what he would do
For female interest to carry through
His plot, if any, for my wife’s at home;
I couldn’t ask her majesty to roam
Amongst my rude adventures—I guess
He’ll find himself in a delightful mess.
He’ll want a heroine, the rules despotic—
Hollo! that gin, by jingo, is narcotic. [Yawns.
Where can he find one? Out of some French play,
No doubt; that will be, then, the usual way.
French thought, French plot, French wit, French moral, cast,
And published, probably, by French, at last.
I’m going—going—gone. [Sleeps. R.C. in chair change

stage.l: Music Without whistle flats open (Circle) Columbia descends on Mote when infront [?] close up. Sing.
Get Ready Ship behind very quietly.

div.stage: COLUMBIA appears in luminous opening, at back—comes forward and touches COLUMBUS, who starts, and looks at her with astonishment.

lg.l: Hollo, ma’m, who are you, for gracious sake— R.H.
Attired in such extraordinary guise?
It’s strange you should exhibit such surprise.
Don’t you know your own child?
I’m not so wise
A father.

sp.speaker: Colum.
sp.l: No! nor yet old Uncle Sam?

lg.l: Well, his niece I am,
In fact the genius of the mighty land
On which will rest your name and fame.
I understand.
You’re Hail Columbia, then—well, I declare,
I’m very glad to see you—take a chair.
From your cap and spangled bodice,
I took you first for Crawford’s sculptured Goddess.
And so I am—myself and Liberty
Are one

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: Thus, undivided may you ever be.

lg.l: Pray tell me, if you please,
Are you that same liberty Demosthenes
So thundered for, until the cute invader
Beneath the patriot espied the trader,
And putting golden pebbles, it is said,
Into his mouth, shut up his noisy head?

That your investments here were just as safe

But see, ‘tis morning—your effects are stored,
The ship awaits us—shall we go on board?
Conveying Liberty, that humble bark
Unharmed shall ride, and like the primal ark,
Where its keel rests another world arise,
And Freedom hang its shingle on the skies.
Are my prophetic visions, then, so near
Fulfilment? Oh, I feel uncommon queer;
Is it ambition so distracts my head,

Before you—even periling your life.

I’ll take the risk. Behold our banner spread! [Displays flag.

“Nuf ced.”

Should a factious hand dare
Its proud folds to impair,
May it withering fall, and Columbia still bear
Her own star-spangled banner, forever to wave
O’er the land of the free and the home of the brave.

note.p: Initialisms are used throughout the promptbook to indicate the nature of entrances and exits as well as scene and/or backdrop changes. Brougham’s Temptation, or, The Irish Emigrant: A Comic Drama in Two Acts (Samuel French 1856) provides this helpful gloss:

L. means First Entrance, Left. R. First Entrance, Right. S.E.L. Second Entrance, Left. S.E.R. Second Entrance, Right. U.E.L. Upper Entrance, Left. U.E.R. Upper Entrance, Right. C. Centre. L.C. Left of Centre. R.C. Right of Centre. T.E.L. Third Entrance, Left. T.E.R. Third Entrance, Right. C.D. Centre Door. D.R. Door Right. D.L. Door Left. U.D.L. Upper Door, Left. U.D.R. Upper Door, Right. *** The Reader is supposed to be on the Stage, facing the Audience

The Columbus Reconstructed promptbook uses similar initialisms but occasionally with the addition of numbers 1-3 or the letters H, N, or G. We believe the numbers indicate order (First, Second, Third), that H may refer to Hand (as in Right Hand First Entrance), and N to North. G likely denotes Groove, or a pulley system with different grooves in the floor that allowed upright painted scenes, known as flats, to change by sliding across the stage in late eighteenth- and early nineteenth-century productions. Overhead rigging largely replaced flats and grooves by the 1860s.

noteGrp.note: Feminine representation of the island of Manhattan, a stand-in for the City of New York.
Feminine representation of the state of Massachusetts.
Feminine representation of the state of Pennsylvania, also known as the Keystone State.

A “Chinese lantern” seems to be a “magic lantern” or “phantasmagoria” technology, which involved the use of multiple painted slides mounted on a mobile light projector to create static, moving, growing, or shrinking images. (Terence Rees, Theatre Lighting in the Age of Gas, London: The Society of Theatre Research, pp. 81-84). The list of lanterns and transparencies here and subsequent stage directions for both Act 1, scene 3, and Act 2, scene 2, indicate that productions of the Columbus burlesque applied a variety of contemporary image technologies.
A transparency “consisted of a painting on a canvas or linen, lighted from behind” (Rees, Theatre Lighting in the Age of Gas, p. 120).

Also “sound on the goose question,” slang for a supporter of slavery, especially during the “Bleeding Kansas” conflicts of the 1850s, though in the subsequent decade, it evolved to mean politically conventional (Emmett Redd and Etcheson, Nicole, “‘Sound on the Goose’: A Search for the Answer to an Age Old ‘Question’,” Kansas History, vol. 32, no. 3, 2009, p. 206).
The ubiquity of the Columbus icon extended to commercial products in the mid-nineteenth-century, as evidenced by this list.
May refer to the rabbits being covered with small spots. OED Online, tick, v.1 3b.

Solon Shingle was a bumbling, innocently obtrusive comic Yankee figure with a love for applesauce (a.k.a. “apple sass”) who first appeared in Joseph Stevens Jones’s drama The People’s Lawyer (1839). Shingle, as performed by George Handel Hill, was such a hit that Yankee performer John E. Owens adapted the play in 1864, titled it Solon Shingle, and performed the role with great success. One gets a sense of the character from lyrics on accompanying sheet music.

An official message (a dispatch) sent via an electromagnetic telegraph machine. The technology was developed by Samuel F. B. Morse (1791-1872) in the 1830s and 1840s, and by the 1850s was a well-established way of sending information quickly across long distances.

“Fire” was a fireworks-like lighting effect in the theater, created when metal powder (composition based on the desired color) was placed in a steel box and ignited (Rees, Theatre Lighting in the Age of Gas, pp. 150-51).
A prop egg resting on a tray stands ready for Diego to carry in for the final scene.
British Quaker William Penn (1644-1718) founded the colony of Pennsylvania on the land of the Lenape Delaware and Iroquois peoples after receiving a charter from King Charles II in 1681.

Myles Standish (1584?–1656) was an English soldier selected over John Smith to serve as the Pilgrims’ military leader when they immigrated to Plymouth colony in 1620. Instrumental in the military and political history of the colony, Standish became a popular icon in the nineteenth century through Henry Wadsworth Longfellow’s largely apocryphal The Courtship of Myles Standish (1858).
Brougham adds a gag concerning Diego as a popcorn vendor to the post-bellum version. Popcorn was a popular street food at the time.

A hard cookie flavored with ginger, akin to a ginger snap. OED Online, ginger n. and adj. 1, C2. A popular street food in nineteenth-century America, the ginger nut makes an appearance in Herman Melville’s “Bartleby, the Scrivener” (1853) as the nickname for an office errand boy who fetches snacks for other workers, including “that peculiar cake—small, flat, round, and very spicy.”

A direct reference to the recently ended Civil War. Brougham depicts the war’s “battle fires” as “unneeded” and at the same time imagines the nation’s “sole taint,” i.e. slavery, eliminated through “freedom’s sacred flame."
A container for liquids made from small animal skins. OED Online, skin, n. 4a.
A"person of a specified...character or type,” here modified by lucky. OED Online, cuss, n. 2.

Diego declares he will no longer sell his wares in the street now that he has employment at court. This is likely a pun on the closing lines of Puritan poet Anne Bradstreet’s “Verses upon the Burning of our House, July 10th, 1666” (1678), which read: “Farewell, my pelf, farewell, my store. / The world no longer let me love, / My hope and treasure lies above.”
In this staging, the flats (painted scenery) part, Columbia descends to the front of the stage, and then she stands on a mound (mote). See first note on stage directions.
Gaslighting is lowered for the conflict that opens the scene.
Applesauce. See earlier note on Solon Shingle.

Derisive taunt. Booth Tarkington’s The Magnificent Ambersons (1918) refers to "pull down your vest" as “the accustomed argot of street badinage” in the postbellum period and in A Tramp Abroad (1880), Mark Twain imagines two crows hurling that and other insults at him. In his 1891 American Slang Dictionary, James Maitland refers to this as “one of the absurd street sayings which from time to time flourish and fade.”
Unclear directions, but perhaps Columbia moves to cover Columbus with the flag once he kneels and the circle of discordant politicians would move downstage.
The 1865-66 Chincha Islands War began when Spain took control of the guano-rich islands from its former colony, Peru.
Sir Samuel Morton Peto (1809–1889), an English railroad contractor, and his partner, Edward Betts, filed for bankruptcy in 1866.
When Columbus El Filibustero!! premiered, there were just 29 states. Minnesota, Oregon, Kansas, West Virginia, and Nevada were added between 1858 and 1864, bringing the total to 36.

Colorado Territory was organized in 1861 and did not become a state until 1876. “Plains Wars” or “Indian Wars” between Native and non-Native forces marked the region during this time. In 1864, Colonel John Chivington and a volunteer militia of white men murdered around 500 Southern Cheyenne and Arapaho men, women, and children in what came to be known as the Sand Creek Massacre. Colorado’s territorial governor, John Evans, supported Chivington. Evans also advocated for statehood, though Colorado’s voters initially rejected the state’s constitution and statehood bid. “Little Miss Colorado” thus replaces “Little Miss Kansas” as the source of discord in Brougham’s closing scene.
The plural of tableau, a theatrical device common in the nineteenth century wherein action stopped and actors held poses to emphasize a significant scene.

Unclear addition. In the dialogue added around the revelation of the Temple of Fame, the King’s lines are interspersed with what seem to be portions of the lines to be spoken by Columbus (indicated by long dashes).

Perhaps indicates that the Americas, which Columbus claims to have discovered, constitute one third of the earth. According to WorldAtlas, the actual fraction of the earth’s landmass constituted by North and South America is 26.9%.
In nineteenth-century jargon, “a large specimen of its kind.” OED Online, bouncer, n. 4.
Likely a reference to the ambitions of some nineteenth-century filibusteros.
Pierre Blot was the author of the popular cookbook, What to Eat, and How to Cook It (1863).

William Tecumseh Sherman (1820-91) was a U.S. Army General remembered for his campaign of property destruction he oversaw in the Confederacy near the close of the Civil War. George Washington (1732-99) was the Commander of the Continental Army during the American Revolutionary War and the first US President. Philip Henry Sheridan (1831-88) was a US Army General revered for his Civil War leadership. In the 1860s he oversaw the brutal U.S. campaign against the Plains Indians.

Three Generals for the Continental Army during the Revolutionary War: Nathanael Greene (1742-86), Joseph Warren (1741-75; he died in battle before receiving his commission), and Israel Putnam (1718-90). Productions seemed to have varied those included in the final spectacle. The program for an 1867 production of Columbus Reconstructed at the Walnut Street Theatre in Philadelphia refers to this portion of the Temple as inhabited by “a selection of the Heroes of the Revolution--General Warren, [Henry] Knox, Putnam, &c.”
